speaker: Frasier
text: And sadly, no one was able to answer today's psychological mind-teaser, so once again the prize goes unclaimed.  By the way, today's answer was "anhedonia."  Anhedonia. [_chuckles_] This is Dr. Frasier Crane, saying good day Seattle, and good mental health.

speaker: Kenny
text: [_low whistle_] That was a real brain-bender, Doc.  You know, the idea is to let people win once in a while.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh please, Kenny, I will not pander.  When some lucky individual looks at his prize, I want him to be able to say, "I earned this."

speaker: Kenny
text: It's an antenna ball!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well...

speaker: Kenny
text: [_as Roz comes in_] Oh Roz, I got some good news! Your documentary is a go!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, that's great!  Thank you, Kenny! [_hugs him_]

speaker: Kenny
text: Congratulations!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, you're doing a documentary?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah well, I've been wanting to do something on my own, so I thought I'd do a special on space - what with it being 2001 and all.  We're gonna do the Cassini mission to Saturn, and telerobotics, that kind of stuff.

speaker: Kenny
text: [_re: Frasier_] You got a show, [_re: Roz_] you got a show -- I don't know who to kiss up to anymore!

speaker: Roz
text: You don't have to kiss up to anyone.

speaker: Kenny
text: Ho-ho-ho!  I wish I didn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: So Roz, you're a space nerd!

speaker: Roz
text: I wouldn't go that far.  There is just something about rockets, though.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, indeed. [_Orson Welles voice_] Roz, sounds like your show could be a portal from which we can glimpse the promise of the future - a promise linked by a billion stars.  God speed, Roz Doyle.

speaker: Roz
text: You wouldn't by any chance be hoping to narrate this, would you?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_innocent_] Me?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, actually I was gonna ask you, but I was afraid it might be kind of awkward, you working for me.  I mean, you've been my boss for eight years.  I just wasn't sure if you could handle it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Roz, pooh!  I welcome a little role reversal, I think it'll do our relationship a lot of good.

speaker: Roz
text: As long as you promise it won't be a problem.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, of course not.  Gosh, you know, actually I'm kind of excited.  You may not know this, but as a tyke I had my heart set on space flight. [_sighs_] Tragic, isn't it?  How a child's dreams can be squashed by a single ride on a diabolically speedy Tilt-A-Whirl?  _He leaves.  FADE OUT  Scene Two - Apartment Martin is seated at the coffee table with a heaping bowl of chili. With slow, reverent movements, he breaks soup crackers into the bowl, tucks a large napkin into his collar, then takes the first spoonful and raises it to his lips-  The doorbell rings._

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, jeez!

speaker: Niles
text: Hey.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey Niles, just in time for chili!  It's my best batch all week.

speaker: Niles
text: Do you ever miss vegetables?

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting back down_] For your information, College, the bean is a vegetable.  So what's new with Daphne?  How are things at the Fat Farm?

speaker: Niles
text: It's a spa.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, sorry.  How are things at the Fat Spa? [_eats a spoonful_]

speaker: Niles
text: Fine, fine.  She's doing very well.  She's losing weight and gaining friends.  Uh Dad, I had an idea about something you and I could do together, you know?  Did you happen to read the Arts & Leisure section today?

speaker: Martin
text: The jumble?  Did it, "A good man is hard to find."

speaker: Niles
text: Actually, I was thinking of something a little loftier.

speaker: Niles
text: [_after a pause_] Dad, do you remember when Frasier was in college, a little tradition you and I had every spring?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, the kite festival?

speaker: Niles
text: Mmm-hmm.

speaker: Martin
text: I thought they didn't do that anymore.

speaker: Niles
text: They're bringing it back this year!  I want us to enter, just like old times!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, we made some good kites, didn't we?

speaker: Niles
text: Great kites!  The "Blue Baron."

speaker: Martin
text: The "Screaming Meamie."

speaker: Niles
text: The "Shield of Perseus."

speaker: Martin
text: You came up with that one, didn't you?

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.  So, what do you say?  You want to do it?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh-ho, I'd love to, Niles.  But I can't fly kites anymore, not with my hip.

speaker: Niles
text: Let me be your hip.  We'll build it together, and then I'll fly it.  I'm old enough now!

speaker: Martin
text: What the hell?  You know, I'm gonna go make some sketches. You know, I always wanted to try a dragon.

speaker: Niles
text: That's a great idea!  We'll name it Fafnir, after Siegfried's fiery nemesis!

speaker: Martin
text: Maybe we'll just make a fish. **SPACE ISN'T BIG ENOUGH FOR THE TWO OF US** _Scene Three - Conference Room Roz is seated at the head of the conference table with two scriptwriters, Ed and B.K.  April, a secretary, stands behind her._

speaker: Roz
text: And before we get started on the script, I have a couple of production notes.  Ed, can you get me forty more seconds of the Mir transmissions?

speaker: Ed
text: No problem.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello everyone, I'm terribly sorry I'm late.  Please, continue. Lead on, maestra.  _He sits down, and as Roz resumes, he mouths words at the secretary, who doesn't understand._

speaker: Roz
text: OK.  Kenny's only giving me a couple of hours to record, so we'll do the big chunks first and the third two's last. And if we have any time at the end of the session, we'll tape the promos - Frasier, what are you doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, Roz, I-I was just looking for a little caffeine kick-start.

speaker: Roz
text: Can it wait until we have a break?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, of course it can.  You're the maestra.

speaker: Roz
text: Can you please stop calling me that? [_he makes an OK sign_] Does everybody have a script?

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.

speaker: Ed
text: Got it.

speaker: B.K.
text: Got it.

speaker: Roz
text: Now, I think basically we're in good shape, but I felt like it dragged a little in the middle.  Any thoughts?

speaker: Ed
text: I agree.  Uh, maybe we should talk about the social aspects -- the panic that spread through the schools because they weren't emphasizing space-

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I like that!  Good idea.

speaker: B.K.
text: What about the space program as a tool for the politicians?

speaker: Roz
text: Good angle!  These are great ideas, guys, keep 'em coming.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I thought we might intercut between the Russian and American programs and build up the tension of the space race.

speaker: Roz
text: I don't think so.

speaker: Ed
text: What about that dog the Russians sent up?

speaker: Roz
text: I love that!  People like dogs!

speaker: Frasier
text: How about those chimps?

speaker: Roz
text: I don't know.  I mean, this isn't "Zoo in Space."  So, uh, it looks like we're filled out in the middle here, so I think we're doing OK.

speaker: Roz
text: What, Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's just a teeny thing, Roz.  I was thinking that, seeing as how it is the jumping-off place for the future, that we might devote two segments to the International Space Station.

speaker: Roz
text: Thanks, but I've worked this out very specifically.

speaker: B.K.
text: You know, I was thinking we could combine the stuff about the manned and unmanned missions into one segment and spread out the space station.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I like that!  Good idea, B.K.

speaker: Frasier
text: I just said that.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I didn't hear you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you must have heard me, Roz, because you said no!

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, let's move on, shall we?  OK, let's talk music.

speaker: B.K.
text: What if we lead off the program with the music from "2001: A Space Odyssey"?

speaker: Roz
text: Home run, B.K.!  _Frasier starts uhm-ing and ah-ing, shaking his head and clenching his fists._

speaker: Roz
text: What is it, Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it - not to belittle your suggestion, B.K., which I love -- it's just that particular piece of music, uh, has been a bit, ah, I don't know, a bit... overused.  And it occurs to me that perhaps an equally evocative, but less familiar piece of music might better serve.  Thank you.

speaker: Ed
text: You mean something like "The Planets" by Holst?

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly, it's a little less on the nose.

speaker: B.K.
text: What about Phillip Glass?  You know, go completely minimalist.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's like space!  Now we're cooking!

speaker: B.K.
text: Have you listened to Sun Ra?  It's from the sixties.

speaker: Frasier
text: This is good!

speaker: Ed
text: For the American program, we can use American music, like Copeland.

speaker: Frasier
text: Better yet, Charles Ives!  And then for the Russians, we can use-

speaker: April
text: Shostakovich!

speaker: Frasier
text: Let's do it!

speaker: Roz
text: FRASIER!  Can I talk to you for a second?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes, of course, Roz.  You're the boss.  Be back in five, everybody.

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, listen Roz, let me give you just one little piece of advice.  I find that when I'm in a leadership position, the best way to rally my staff-

speaker: Roz
text: What staff?!  I'm your staff, and I've been listening to you for eight years, and I would like for you to listen to me for a change!

speaker: Frasier
text: And I support that-

speaker: Roz
text: Then SHUT UP!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sulky_] Well... I'm not sure that's a very wise tone to take if you don't want to lose your narrator.

speaker: Roz
text: Is that a threat?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm just saying that alienating me isn't probably in the best interests of the show.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, maybe "the show" would be better off without you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, then maybe I should just leave "the show."

speaker: Roz
text: Well, maybe that's what "the show" wants you to do.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well then, "the show" can BITE ME!  _He leaves.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Four Frasier is back doing his show._

speaker: Frasier
text: I realize I've gone on here a bit, Fred, so let me try to boil this down for you: if you want to be a good leader, you've got to be able to admit when you're wrong. [_turns a gimlet eye toward Roz_] No one ever stood so tall as when he - or _she_ - stooped to say, "I'm sorry."

speaker: Fred
text: [_v.o._] What's that got to do with my fear of intimacy?

speaker: Frasier
text: Which brings to mind another phrase: "There is none so blind as he"-or _she_ -"who will not see."  We'll be right back after the news.

speaker: Roz
text: [_through mike_] Subtle, Frasier.  But just so you know, I do not owe you an apology.  You were trying to take over my show, and that's why I fired you.

speaker: Frasier
text: You did not fire me, I quit.  But at this late date, Roz, you should be spared the burden of having to replace me. So, why don't we agree to put aside our egos and continue with the program?

speaker: Roz
text: I've already replaced you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz.  You've gone with an "also-ran."  Who is it?

speaker: Roz
text: John Glenn.

speaker: Frasier
text: The astronaut?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: The senator?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes.  _The_ John Glenn, American hero.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_only card left_] So I take it there was nobody available with any previous radio experience. **SEATTLE, WE HAVE A PROBLEM**  _Scene Five - Apartment Martin stands behind the couch, holding up a dragon kite. Niles is standing across the room with the string and spool._

speaker: Martin
text: Loosen up, son. [_Niles does_] That's the way.  Relaxed, but firm.  It's not a fight, it's a persuasion.

speaker: Niles
text: OK, Dad, I am ready.  I want to take her to the park.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, out of the question!

speaker: Niles
text: I have to practice in real-life conditions, I can't keep running up and down the halls!

speaker: Martin
text: No, it's too windy!

speaker: Niles
text: All right, well, uh, can I at least hang her off the balcony so we can see how she looks?

speaker: Martin
text: Niles, what kind of dope are you smoking?  The updraft would pull you off your feet!  You know, you've got a lot to learn. This isn't like driving a car, you know, it takes practice and concentration.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Fras.  Did you get things all patched up with Roz?

speaker: Frasier
text: On the contrary, every time I offer her an olive branch, she snaps it in two, sets it on fire, and writes "NO" with the ashes!  She had the temerity to call me overbearing! This time the wound is deep, my friends, bone deep!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, maybe-

speaker: Frasier
text: [_pouring sherry_] Oh yes, of course sometimes I am forceful with my opinions, but that is only because I'm passionate! And right!  And passionate about being right!  "Overbearing," as if!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, she probably wants to-

speaker: Frasier
text: It's insupportable, Dad!  She went out and got John Glenn to replace me!

speaker: Niles
text: The astronaut?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, the American hero!

speaker: Martin
text: John Glenn?  He's perfect!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, moondust and starshine, Dad!  Yes, [_contemptuous_] he's "been to space."  But does he have the voice, the savvy, the radio charisma, hmm?!

speaker: Martin
text: Batten down the kite, Niles, it's really starting to blow hard in here.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, your issues notwithstanding, getting John Glenn is quite a coup for Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: John Glenn is just a space-age Band-Aid, Niles, and Roz is using him to cover up this enormous authority issue she has with me, which she persists in denying!

speaker: Niles
text: Um-

speaker: Frasier
text: You're right, Niles, it's time for action!  I have got to show her once and for all that I am not some meddler and she is only being paranoid!  Now I'll be in my room, plotting some way to prove it! _Frasier leaves the room.  Niles picks up the kite and admires it. Smiling at Eddie, he holds up the kite like a mask and advances. Eddie growls.  He gets an idea - why not?  He looks at Eddie and raises a finger to his lips.  Then he opens the balcony, letting in the roar of the wind.  Eddie watches as:  Holding the spool, Niles takes the kite out onto the balcony - and the wind tears it out of his hands and up into the air.  He hangs onto the spool for dear life as the string unwinds, reaching its end and dragging him back and forth.  As Niles fights to regain control, the kite suddenly swoops down past the balcony, yanking him over the rail and pulling his feet off the ground.  Just as he is about to go over, the kite swoops back up, jerking him upright and hitting something on the roof.  Niles pulls himself back inside and shuts the door on the string, blocking out the wind.  The building's satellite dish crashes onto the balcony.  CUT TO:  Martin's Room: Martin is lying on his bed, watching TV and speaking on the phone._

speaker: Martin
text: All I know is that a couple of your clowns wired up the dish a month ago, and now I can't even see the news.  Now I do a lot of TV-watching, and I don't want to have to take my business elsewhere, but I will!  _The kite slams into his balcony window and comes to a rest. Eddie runs in and growls at it._

speaker: Martin
text: [_faking static noises into the phone_] Can't hear you, sorry. [_hangs up_] _FADE TO:  Scene Six - Conference Room John Glenn is seated at the table with a copy of the script. Frasier knocks and comes in._

speaker: Frasier
text: Senator?

speaker: Glenn
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'd like to introduce myself.  I'm Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Glenn
text: [_shaking hands_] Oh, glad to meet you.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a pleasure to meet you.  I was the previous narrator on the documentary.

speaker: Glenn
text: That's a fascinating story.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you've heard her side of the story, maybe someday you'll hear mine.

speaker: Glenn
text: Well, I was talking about space travel.  It was good of you to step aside, though - you have a scheduling conflict?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, unfortunately.  The Opera Guild's annual... football tournament.  Well, I'm the quarterback.  Anyway, uh, here, if you wouldn't mind indulging me-

speaker: Glenn
text: Sure.

speaker: Frasier
text: I have a few suggestions that I didn't have a chance to run by Roz. [_takes out some notes_] Um, here we are.  Now this first one is about a Seattle man who took his two sons to the roof to see if they could spot Friendship-7 flying by.

speaker: Glenn
text: Was that you?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's very perceptive of you, sir, yes.  That was me, my father, and my brother.  I thought a story from the glory days of space might help to launch the show.

speaker: Glenn
text: You know, that sounds great.  I'll bring that up to Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, about that - it's probably best that Roz never know we had this conversation.

speaker: Glenn
text: Why not?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you see, any suggestion that came from me right now, Roz would be inclined to shoot down, and uh, she's still a little ticked off at me for dropping out.

speaker: Glenn
text: Well, you know, I don't like to go behind someone's back-

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, we're not going behind anybody's back!  Even if we were, it's only temporary!  At any rate, it is for the good of the show.

speaker: Glenn
text: Well, OK.  I'll look through these things and I'll probably bring them up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's terrific.  Thank you, sir.  It was a pleasure to meet you.  Take care. [_starts to leave_] Oh, Senator?  Uh, what do you drink up there, Tang?

speaker: Glenn
text: [_checks his watch_] Two minutes and twenty seconds: a new record. _FADE TO:  Scene Seven - Radio Booth Glenn is seated in Frasier's booth, with Roz._

speaker: Roz
text: So let me get this cued up, and we'll be ready to go, OK?

speaker: Glenn
text: Sounds great.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, what are you doing here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I'm just observing.  If you want me to go, I will, but you have to admit this is sort of a once-in-a-lifetime thing.

speaker: Roz
text: Fine.  But no talking.

speaker: Roz
text: [_through mike_] OK, Senator, we're rolling.

speaker: Glenn
text: OK.  Roz, I have an idea if you're interested.

speaker: Roz
text: Sure.

speaker: Glenn
text: I heard the nicest story, about a Seattle man who took his two sons up on the roof of the house, to try and see my Mercury spacecraft come over.

speaker: Roz
text: I love that!

speaker: Glenn
text: Yeah, well, I thought you'd like that one.  And then, if we could get some of the old mission broadcasts, maybe we could use those for background.

speaker: Roz
text: Definitely!  You are full of great ideas!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_no longer humble_] No, I'M full of good ideas!

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, what are you doing?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, you just agreed to two of my suggestions, which proves your problem is with me and not with them!

speaker: Roz
text: [_through the mike_] I'm so sorry! [_to Frasier_] Frasier, get out!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, it's all right, the Senator and I are old friends! I took the liberty of running a few irresistible ideas by him so that I could prove my point and let you come clean!

speaker: Glenn
text: That's not what you told me.  You used me!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, Senator, but-but if I used you it was only as the swift and terrible sword of justice!

speaker: Roz
text: It's terrible, all right!  And outrageous! [_to Glenn_] You said these were your ideas!  Why'd you do it, Senator Glenn?

speaker: Glenn
text: I was misled, and-and I feel awful, and-and you know, it's not like me to be that underhanded.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, it's all right.  Frasier, get out of my booth!  I am so sorry, Senator Glenn.

speaker: Glenn
text: Well, I'm the one that's sorry.  It's my nature to be honest, and...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_speaking over him_] Now listen up, Roz, I'm gonna tell you what I did this for.

speaker: Glenn
text: Back in those glory days, I was very uncomfortable when they... asked us to say things that I didn't want to say, and deny other things...

speaker: Roz
text: I am so mad at you, Frasier!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yeah, well I'm mad too, so just bring it on!

speaker: Glenn
text: Some people ask, you know, "were you alone out there?"  And we never gave the real answer, and yet we've seen things out there, strange things...

speaker: Roz
text: This is my project, and I asked you not to try to take control, and now you've gone behind my back and done just that!

speaker: Frasier
text: But Roz, you didn't even give me a fair shake!

speaker: Roz
text: Well, if I didn't, it was because I was trying to protect myself because you can be so BOSSY sometimes!

speaker: Glenn
text: But we know what we saw out there, and we couldn't really say anything, and the bosses were scared of this, they were afraid of "War of the Worlds" type-stuff, and about panic in the streets, and so we had to keep quiet, and now we only see these things in our - well, in our nightmares, or maybe in-in the movies, and some of them are pretty close to being the truth...

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Roz, I'll admit that maybe I was being a little too assertive, all right?  But the least you could do is admit that perhaps you were a bit defensive? _Glenn draws the path of a U.F.O. with his finger, zipping and stopping from one point to another with incredible speed, making whishing noises._

speaker: Roz
text: Well, maybe you're right.  But it was because I was trying to prove that I could do this on my own - so I was shutting you out, I admit it, it was unfair, and I apologize.

speaker: Frasier
text: Accepted.  Oh Roz, come on, our friendship is much more important to me than this documentary.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, it is to me too, Frasier!

speaker: Glenn
text: Uh, look, about what I just said out there, could we just keep that between us?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, of course, Senator.

speaker: Glenn
text: Good.  Well... [_notices_] oh, wait!  You were recording all that?

speaker: Roz
text: Well yeah, but that's OK, we've got plenty of tape.

speaker: Glenn
text: [_stern_] I'm gonna need that tape.

speaker: Roz
text: He's a little tightly wound.

speaker: Frasier
text: Looks like maybe somebody should cut back on the old Tang.

speaker: Roz
text: [_laughing_] That's a good one, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Whenever you're ready, Senator.

speaker: Glenn
text: [_reading_] "Since the dawn of time, man has gazed skyward and dreamed of reaching the stars..."
